title: What is the correct syntax of a `for` loop?
explanation: The correct syntax for a 'for' loop in C is `for (initialization; condition; increment/decrement) { /* loop body */ }`. The loop body is enclosed in curly braces '{}'.

title: Array is an example of which of the following?
explanation: Arrays are derived types because they are derived from fundamental data types like int, char, float, etc. They are collections of elements of the same data type.

title: Which of the following is correct about C arrays?
options: Array elements are stored in contiguous memory locations.
Array elements cannot be initialized during declaration.
The size of an array is fixed after declaration.
Both A and C are correct.
explanation: C arrays store elements in contiguous memory locations, and their size is fixed once declared. Array elements can be initialized during declaration.

title: What is the index number of the last element in an array of size 10?
explanation: In C, array indices start from0. Therefore, an array of size10 has indices from0 to9, making9 the index of the last element.

title: Which of the following correctly declares an array in C?
explanation: The correct syntax for declaring an array in C is `data_type array_name[size];`. `int arr[10];` declares an integer array named 'arr' with a size of10.

title: Which of the following is correct about multidimensional arrays in C?
options: They are stored row by row in memory.
They are stored column by column in memory.
The number of dimensions is fixed to2.
explanation: In C, multidimensional arrays are stored in memory row by row. This means all elements of the first row are stored contiguously, followed by elements of the second row, and so on.

title: What does the term 'dynamic array' mean?
options: An array whose size can be altered during runtime.
An array whose size is fixed at compile-time.
An array with fixed size but dynamic initialization.
explanation: A dynamic array is an array whose size can be changed or adjusted during the execution of the program (runtime). This is typically achieved using dynamic memory allocation functions like malloc, calloc, and realloc.

title: ~(100111) gives:
explanation: The '~' operator is the bitwise NOT operator, which flips each bit. So, ~(100111) becomes 011000.

title: Which function is used to dynamically allocate memory in C?
explanation: `malloc`, `calloc`, and `realloc` are all used for dynamic memory allocation in C. `malloc` allocates a block of memory, `calloc` allocates and initializes memory to zero, and `realloc` changes the size of previously allocated memory.

title: What is the default value of an uninitialized array in C?
explanation: Uninitialized arrays in C contain garbage values, which are whatever values were previously stored in the memory locations allocated to the array. The default value is not guaranteed to be 0 or null.

title: Which of the following is used to free dynamically allocated memory in C?
explanation: The correct answer is free() because it is used to free dynamically allocated memory in C.

title: Which of the following correctly accesses the 5th element of an array 'arr'?
explanation: The correct answer is arr[4] because array indices in C start at 0, so the 5th element is at index 4.

title: Under which of the following conditions, the size of the array need not be specified?
options: When initialization is a part of definition
explanation: The correct answer is When initialization is a part of definition because when an array is initialized, the size of the array can be omitted and the compiler will determine the size based on the number of elements in the initializer.

title: Which one of the following is the correct syntax for initialization of one-dimensional arrays?
explanation: The correct answer is int num[3] = {0, 0, 0}; because this is the standard syntax for initializing an array in C.

title: int a[10] will reserve how many locations in the memory?
explanation: The correct answer is 10 because when an array of size 10 is declared, it reserves 10 locations in memory.

title: The size of 'long double' data type in a 16-bit machine is:
explanation: In a 16-bit machine, the size of 'long double' is typically 10 bytes.

title: The range of 'char' data type is:
explanation: The 'char' data type, when treated as a signed type, typically has a range of -128 to 127.

title: The size of 'char' data type is:
explanation: The 'char' data type is always 1 byte (8 bits) in C.

title: The format specifier that is used to read or write a character is:
explanation: '%c' is the format specifier used to read or write a character in C.

title: Which one of the following is a string constant?
explanation: String constants are enclosed in double quotes (""). '"hello"' is a string constant. Single quotes (' ') are used for character constants.

title: If no precision is specified for a floating-point number, then printf() prints _______ decimal positions.
explanation: If no precision is specified for a floating-point number using the '%f' format specifier in printf(), it prints six decimal positions by default.

title: What is the result of 8 | 4?
explanation: 8 in binary is 1000, and 4 in binary is 0100. Performing a bitwise OR operation ( | ) results in 1100, which is 12 in decimal.

title: Which of the following operators is used to combine two or more relational expressions?
explanation: The '&&' operator is the logical AND operator, used to combine two or more relational expressions. '^' is bitwise XOR, '~' is bitwise NOT, and '&' is bitwise AND.

title: 10 << 3 gives:
explanation: The '<<' operator is the left shift operator. Shifting 10 (1010 in binary) by 3 bits to the left results in 1010000, which is 80 in decimal.

title: Shifting a number 'n' by 's' bits to the left is equivalent to which of the following?
explanation: Shifting a number 'n' by 's' bits to the left is equivalent to multiplying 'n' by 2 raised to the power of 's' (n * 2^s).

title: Shifting a number 'n' by 's' bits to the right is equivalent to which of the following?
explanation: Shifting a number 'n' by 's' bits to the right is equivalent to dividing 'n' by2 raised to the power of 's' (n /2^s).

title: _________ operators are used for shifting bits to the right and left.
explanation: The '>>' operator is used for right shifting bits, and the '<<' operator is used for left shifting bits.
